awd_titl_txt: Incorporating Immunity into Epidemiological Infectious Disease Models: Bridging Multiple Scales
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging and on-going infectious disease outbreaks significantly impact the health and economic stability of a population. Understanding and predicting the course of such outbreaks is challenging due to the variability of individuals, particularly with respect to their levels of protection against various infections. This work will address three infectious diseases of worldwide interest: dengue, malaria and whooping cough. Simple mathematical models have been successful at describing the epidemics of and suggesting intervention strategies for simple infectious disease. More complicated diseases, however, require the development and analysis of more complicated models, particularly linking multiple scales - organismal, temporal, and spatial. The novel models and quantitative tools will provide insight into the reason for observed patterns of outbreaks as well as guide strategies for combating these complicated diseases. This work will provide interdisciplinary training for undergraduate and graduate students, and the results of the work will be disseminated to a broad audience through the development of infectious disease based outreach activities and peer-reviewed publications and seminars.


Understanding the role of variable immunity within populations is crucial to accurately determining the dynamics of epidemics and to effectively slowing and stopping their spread. This work includes the development, analysis, and simulation of multi-scale models with variability of the individual host immune response. Detailed within-host immune dynamics will be incorporated into population-level epidemiological models of dengue, malaria and pertussis (whooping cough) to evaluate population-level disease dynamics. The aims of this work are three fold: determine the role of within-host viral and immune variability on epidemiological dynamics of dengue; determine the role of adaptive antigen-specific immunity on malaria prevalence and transmission potential; and develop a model of waning and boosting of immunity to determine optimal primary vaccination and booster dose timing for pertussis. This work furthers the mathematical theory of multi-scale systems of differential equations motivated through the incorporation of within-host heterogeneity in population models. It will build upon mathematical theory from differential equations and non-linear dynamical systems. The main challenge will be analyses of non-linear systems with variable time scales and large dimensionality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Infectious diseases exhibit complicated patterns across a variety of scales. The course of a single infection within an individual is the result of interactions between a disease-causing pathogen and the immune response, while the spread of an outbreak through a population is also determined by the likelihood of interactions between susceptible and infectious individuals. This variability at multiple scales needs to be considered to effectively slow and stop the spread of infectious disease.  This project involved inclusion of variability into novel disease models in two primary ways: incorporating interactions between pathogens and the immune response at a within-host level, and incorporating complex ecological feedbacks into population dynamics of hosts. While the models developed were applied to a range of diseases, the focus of this work was on the mosquito-transmitted pathogen malaria.

The models developed during this project showed the role of multiple blood feeding sessions by mosquitoes as well as the level of initial pathogen taken up by the mosquito to modulate the time until a mosquito is able to transmit the disease, which impacts malaria transmission at a population level. Other work demonstrated how various ecological factors, such as competition during juvenile development of mosquitoes, can greatly affect the size of mosquito populations, another important factor in transmission of malaria and other mosquito-transmitted diseases. The incorporation of these single-scale complexities into a multi-scale model of malaria transmission demonstrated how certain ecological traits, such as low levels of pathogen reproduction, could persist in contrast to classical ecological theory. For directly-transmitted diseases, the incorporation of realistic immunity, in particular the capacity for immunity to wane over time, produced complicated patterns of spread, ranging from oscillations across years to both fixed low and high prevalence. As interventions, by design, change how pathogens spread, an understanding of the range of possible patterns of spread without any intervention is needed. This work built upon the theory of differential equations and non-linear dynamical system to advance our understanding of the spread of infectious diseases. 

Results of this project were widely disseminated within the academic community via invited talks at multiple international conferences and through peer-reviewed published journal articles and book chapters. Beyond academic communities, results of this project were used to enhance public understanding of infectious disease spread and to teach K-12 students such as through presentations at the Blacksburg Math Circle and several summer mathematics programs. Furthermore, this project provided training and professional development opportunities for a postdoc, four graduate students, three undergraduate students, and a high school student.
